text: hi everyone thank you for coming to my talk my name is melissa houghton and i
am a senior consultant from tulsa purple based in melbourne i'm a developer
and i mainly focus on web development in angular and net this talk isn't very technical focus
but i do do some tech stuff so if you want to follow me on twitter or connect on any of the socials uh please do they're they're up
on the screen i also won't really be keeping an eye on the chat but hopefully we'll have some
time at the end to talk so feel free to as i'm going and the slides are mostly
just pretty pictures so if there's any issues with the video which hopefully there's not hopefully that's
not too much of an issue and i've turned on subtitles which hopefully help with anything with sounds
imposter syndrome how many of you have heard of imposter syndrome
if we were in prison i would ask people to raise their hands and i
would expect to see many hands raised if you would not have raised your hand that's okay too you're
in the right place but this is not a new topic it's been covered hundreds of times in
many different ways when i was doing research for this talk i found
hundreds of articles ted talks blog posts all different kinds of things on
imposter syndrome and there were talks by psychologists by educators
by students and business professionals people from all different backgrounds different
genders different ethnicities and professional standing and all of them shared
their research with on imposter syndrome but they also shared their personal experiences with it
if we look into the world of celebrities we can find some familiar faces
of people who have shown experience imposter syndrome maya angelou she's
an american poet and civil rights activist she is an author with dozens of awards
for her work yet she has shared fears of people finding out that she's played a game on
them this whole time lady gaga a musician who always strives
to be different some consider her to be one of the world's best music artists and yet in her documentary she said that
she still feels like that loser kid in high school and has to remind herself every single
day that she is actually a superstar serena williams a professional tennis
player and former number one in the world for women's singles tennis with 23 grand slam titles but despite
her success she says that she feels she lives in her sister's shadow and she struggles to rationalize these
successes now if we go a little bit closer to home into the world of tech
and for people who are actually in city in sydney we see familiar faces there as well mike
from atlassian has done a tedx sydney talk on imposter
syndrome where he discussed his personal battle and his story with it
he shared a story in the talk of when atlassian was coming up as a company
and he was winning entrepreneur of the year awards and the whole time he was feeling like a
fraud and that he did not belong but throughout his journey
he learned that others feel the same way and that that feeling does not go away with success
however he has learned how to not let it hold him back and how to not freeze and he has learned
how to use his fear as motivation and we can do that too
imposter syndrome was first defined in 1978 by clinical psychologists pauline clance
and suzanne ims and they defined it as an internal experience of intellectual phoniness
despite outstanding academic and professional accomplishments so their first initial study focused on
high achieving women specifically but since then there has been many studies done that have proven
imposter syndrome to be prevalent across all genders and imposter syndrome is known by a few
different names so it's also known as imposter phenom phenomenon imposterism and fraud syndrome
but whatever you want to call it it's when you feel like a fraud that you do not deserve the success and
achievements that you are getting and that you don't actually belong and you don't know what you're doing at
the core of it it's the inability to internalize your own success so
who experiences imposter syndrome why do people experience it what does it look like and
how can we battle against it and how can we help others in their battle how can we flip it around
to use it as motivation and turn it into a positive thing that's what i want to talk to you about
today but first why me why am i the one
sitting here talking to you giving you this talk i regularly ask myself this very same
question my very first ever conference talk was on the same subject at ddd sydney
and it was no ordinary talk it was actually the loch net but when i first heard that ddd sydney
wanted me to do the lock note i thought it must be some sort of prank it was my last night
in perth before moving all the way across the country to melbourne and i was leaving a job
as a software developer at bankwest where i had worked for four and a half years
and i was about to start a new role as a senior developer at telstra purple which is a company
that i always looked up to as employing some brilliant and truly amazing people ddd perth
the perth version of the conference had just finished and i had helped organize it and put a ton of work and effort into it i
was having final drinks at the after party with some friends and colleagues and as
it was the last time i was seeing a lot of them because i was moving they were sharing words of
encouragement and praise from their time working with me so there's a ton of different things
going on and with all these things happening i was having an intense internal battle
with imposter syndrome and it was at this very same time that michelle from yao who was
sponsoring the lock note talk approached me to see if i would be available to do the lock note
and my brain jumped immediately to thinking that it must be some big conspiracy there was no way that
the people i looked up to in the tech community or these colleagues that i admired thought so highly of me my subconscious
was telling me they must be up to something but they weren't i was experiencing imposter syndrome and
this actually wasn't the first time i've experienced it i've experienced it many times throughout my
life and i've helped others who have experienced it as well however
the battle continues and it's an ongoing one so when i was still working at bankwest
i had a secondment as the technology graduate program manager
and what that meant is that the 14 grads in the technology reported technology department reported into me
as their manager and i ran and developed the program but most importantly i helped
guide them and help them with any sort of problems they may be facing and the most common problem that they
came to me with were those feelings of not meeting expectations not knowing exactly what they're doing
and questioning why they got the role over somebody else and why they were there
so i talked them through these feelings that they were experiencing and helped them battle against it
because what they were working with was imposter syndrome
although it was a bit ironic because being in that role i felt like an imposter i had just
finished the graduate program myself before moving into managing it i had no
prior management experience and half of the grads who were reporting into me were actually older than me
so the photo on the screen right now is me as the manager with some of the grads and you might be
thinking i like just like them and a lot of people mistook me but still just one of the grads so it's
not that looks or age matter or really made me any less of a leader but these were all factors that fed into
my imposter syndrome and really made it worse so how did i get through this
how did i ensure that these feelings would not hold me back and how did i ensure that i could help
the grads to do the same i came up with a three-step process
to win this battle first i learned to recognize that what i was
experiencing was imposter syndrome recognize when it was happening and what it looked like then
i rationalized the situation i redefined those thoughts and feelings and reframed
them into a new light the people around me were not out to get me
there's no big grand scheme to trick me and really what benefit would they have in
doing so then i reflected on my accomplishments
you know looking back on it i had worked hard i had done well and i use these three things to empower
myself to fight against imposter syndrome i work to flip the beliefs
to prove myself wrong to prove that i'm not an imposter and that i do belong there and i turn the negative thoughts into
positive ones and use that as a motivation and that motivation
encouraged me to say yes and do that lock note at ddd sydney and many other
opportunities along the way when i actually first submitted this talk to ndc
i originally submitted it as a lightning talk mostly because i was afraid of trying to
make an hour-long conference talk but i had an opportunity to change it to
be a long conference talk and submit again and i thought about it and i convinced myself i could do it
and i submitted it and it was accepted but getting myself to that point to get
over my fears was not easy and it has taken a lot of practice
to to get through it and if you struggle with that same thing that is okay we can
work through it together so let's understand how we can recognize
imposter syndrome first let's think about who experiences it
research has shown that 70 of people experience imposter syndrome in some
in some form at some point in their life and that's according to a study that was published in the international journal of
behavioral science and this can happen once or many times but for most people
it is a truly an ongoing battle mike from atlassian found that imposter
syndrome does not go away with success but really anyone at any level can experience it you don't
always have to be successful to be experiencing imposter syndrome and some people are predisposed and
more likely to experience imposter syndrome than others and these are people
from underrepresented communities so like myself a female in tech i i fit
right in there or people that see themselves as an outsider or are a minority people who
have struggled with mental health issues or have experienced abuse or high levels of
criticism or people who are just naturally talented and have always had those really high expectations on
them think about serena williams she grew up in her sister's shadow and was always
expected to be a big tennis star so these people are experiencing imposter syndrome
but also people who are continuing to learn and outside of their comfort zone if
you're breaking new ground you're more likely to feel these insecurities
a lot of the research i came across was conducted on graduate level university students
and they were actually found to experience imposter syndrome at a higher rate than others and
this is because they're in a competitive and stressful environment they're outside of their comfort zones
and outside of their depth of knowledge and continuing to learn new things
they're questioning why they were accepted into the program over someone else comparing themselves to the classmates
or people they may see as more successful in tech
we are continually learning new things and i believe this these same theories
apply to us we're doing research and we're reading articles and publishing articles
ourselves we're spending our time attending conferences like this to stay up to date and on top of everything that's coming
up in the tech world we're continuing to study and earn those certifications
and it's easy for even a senior someone with lots of experience to be outshined by a junior who knows
more about that new piece of technology so we have to try to stay up to date and
ahead of the curve and sometimes we find ourselves competing to keep up so that is why imposter syndrome is such
an essential topic in the tech community
so what does imposter syndrome look like it can look like this cartoon where we
have trouble accepting compliments we can make up excuses or just brush it
off saying oh yeah we're lucky we're in the right place at the right time we tend to undermine our achievements
and discount any sort of praise and when it comes to delivering work we tend
to over prepare or just really procrastinate or like i tend to do for my talks and
things some weird crazy combination of the two but we can be workaholics or
perfectionists or really just avoid tasks altogether for fear of failing
and not living up to those expectations and those people that are naturally talented who have always
been told that they're the smart one they tend to get frustrated if they don't actually get it right away
and they also have that fear of failure but imposter syndrome usually is an
internal struggle we don't always verbalize these feelings that we're having and sometimes we work hard to cover it
up because we're worrying that people will find out that we're a fraud and that we don't belong so if we notice
ourselves or anyone else around us doing things and like this they might be experiencing
imposter syndrome and to further help us recognize imposter syndrome
dr valerie young has identified that there are five subtypes of imposter syndrome that you
may fall into the first is the perfectionist
so this type looks at how well they've done something they see success only as a hundred
percent perfection and anything short of that is considered a failure they focus on
what could have been better or what went wrong they're your friend who gives that presentation and after
and you're like hey you did a great job and after the words they're like oh no i forgot this and messed up this
only focusing on those negative aspects the next is the natural genius
so this type looks at how and when accomplishments happen they focus on how easily it came to them
and the speed that they were able to achieve it and they're the ones that tend to get frustrated
if they don't get it the first time and often they can feel shame if they don't get it right away because
they feel it should come naturally the third is the superhero this type
likes to juggle tons of different roles at once and their success is based on being able to do all of them really well
so falling short and even one of them is considered a failure and they feel they should be able to
handle it even if their play is completely overloaded so this type tends to have problems with
burnout and just being completely over committing themselves
the fourth is the expert so this looks at what and how much they know they measure
their competence by the volume of knowledge or skill and they fear being exposed as inexperienced
and they see lack of knowledge as a failure and the fifth one is the soloist so
this type cares who completes the task they see a task as an achievement only
when they completed it by themselves they're the ones who tend to give credit to the other people on the project
or luck or the resources that they may have had available to them and they often see asking for help as a
sign of failure so the type of imposter syndrome that you or someone you know
may be experiencing can fall into multiple categories and it depends on the situation
but being aware of these different types can help us to recognize and identify imposter syndrome
i know for me my imposter syndrome tends to fall into the perfectionist or the
superhero range when i'm more in the perfectionist side tasks can become too daunting
because i know it'd be hard to deliver up to the standard that i have set for myself
so then i just try to avoid them all together but once i do start i overwork and over
stress because i am trying to get it to that 100 perfect state
but really having the ability to recognize these can help us keep imposter syndrome down
so what are the risks with imposter syndrome why why do we want to understand it and
recognize it why can it be dangerous what happens when we start to lose the battle
losing to imposter syndrome can lead to increased depression and unhappiness it
can lead to general life dissatisfaction it can hold us back from accepting new
roles or opportunities or even just applying in the first place it can prevent us from sharing our ideas
and our opinions from speaking up in a meeting and having our voices heard it can lead to lack of motivation
and it can lead to burnout when i was in the graduate program
manager role i had taken on more responsibility than i ever had before
i had 14 direct reports and i was completely out of my comfort zone at the same time
i was trying to keep up with all the volunteer user groups and conferences and things i was involved in
outside of work perfectly fitting into that superhero subtitle but i found myself over
committed i was losing motivation and i no longer believed in my abilities and on top of that i was
constantly feeling like a fraud like they had made a mistake in giving me that role and i was not
happy in the role and i was not happy in my life and really i was constantly overwhelmed
but thankfully after a while i was able to recognize what was happening and that something
needed to change i cut back on commitments but those negative thoughts and feelings
of an impostor remained but now i was able to recognize they were there and move on to the next step in my
process which is to rationalize them so i i fought against the negative thoughts
and that were holding me back i thought through does this make sense i redefined
what was happening and try to reframe the situation i looked at the facts and tried to
practice thinking like a non-imposter thinking that i did belong there
it doesn't make sense for people to play a prank on me right now how likely was it that somebody is going
to run up on stage while i'm giving the lock note and pull me off or jump on this call
right now and tell me to stop because it was just some big joke the whole time not very likely
i hope but how do we rationalize these thoughts and feelings and how do we reframe them into a new
line well there are two main methods to redefining imposter syndrome the first
is thought stopping so this method is about stopping the negative thoughts in their tracks and replacing them with
positive ones often our negative thoughts form a pattern
and we get ourselves into a negative feedback loop that digs us deeper deeper into a bad
place so i always have before i do a presentation uh these thoughts coming into my head
that i'm just gonna completely mess it up you know everything is going to go wrong it'll be a big disaster everyone
will find out i'll never be able to do a talk again and on and on and on and the farther we
go down the more at risk we are of losing that battle so we have to notice those thoughts
recognize them catch them as early on as we can and really stop them
but then we combat it with positive thoughts once you recognize and and stop them bring up a positive voice
in your head that non-imposter that's saying yes you can do it
even if initially you don't believe it continuing to say it will help reinforce the positive
messages and stop the negative thoughts in their tracks because the thoughts and feelings
that we're having do not define our actions unless we allow them to
the second method is thought shipping and this is the idea of not waiting
until your idea or thing is perfect before launch
it's very similar to that agile way of thinking to fail fast and ship it i wore my
azure devops ship it t-shirt today to help remind me that even though i don't
feel like this talk is at that 100 perfectionist level it's good enough and i should just
ship it it's that 70 rule that is used by the u.s navy
and they see as a decision-making process that when you have 70 of the information
make the call and keep moving because keep moving keeps you safe
it means you're less vulnerable and it provides that opportunity to adjust and grow and learn it's that very agile
fail fast and learn faster it's the same concept that mike ken brooks and his talk described
as not freezing thought shipping can push us outside of our comfort zones
and stimulate growth and creativity while building up self-compassion for ourselves by
allowing us to forgive our mistakes so try both methods and really figure out
which works best for you but it's all about practice and keep moving forward
but do you continue to rationalize sometimes it's hard to just do it by
yourself so it's important that we talk about it share the feelings with other people
and lean on others when they become too heavy to bear as imposters we fear that someone
will find out that we are a fraud and we have this fear that will be exposed
so naturally we tend to avoid sharing feelings but talking about it is precisely what we need to do
these conversations help us to get affirmation that what we're feeling is normal and
that it's probably not true mike in his journey discussed how he felt
that he was alone feeling like a fraud but he spoke to other people who were nominated for the
same award and he found out he wasn't and that was his libel moment that really drove him to
win the battle and for me i enjoy sharing my experience with other people
because it helps me to keep moving forward and reinforce those ideas that this is a natural thing to
experience and many people share with me that they experience the same thing
so when imposter syndrome is taking hold you may feel alone but trust me you're
not now it's not all about those achievements and accomplishments and
doing really well sometimes we do fail so it's important to remember that that is okay imposter syndrome
is accompanied by this underlying fear of failure so to help us to continue to rationalize
we need to keep failure in perspective and redefine what does it mean to fail
imposters like to use not succeeding as proof that they're a fraud but really we need
to learn to fight it because failure is inevitable we can learn how to get back up and how
to move forward from failure reframe and redefine how we see it as
as a learning experience or an opportunity for growth or a way we can improve i
am always worried that people are not actually going to come to my session and my initial thought is that if no one
did it would be failure but would it really be a failure it was a great success for me to have a
talk accepted to ndc in the first place and i can reframe it as that stepping stone and a learning
experience breaking things into smaller achievable goals
i had a goal this year to submit talks to conferences and the next step was to then have talks
accepted after that is having people attend and so then i can revisit and update the goals continue to learn
and move forward maybe next time get more talks accepted or more people attending
failure is all a part of success so after we've recognized and
rationalized we then need to keep those feelings at bay and we can use the last step
which is reflection and all three of these steps work together to really build up our
ability to win the battle with imposter syndrome so take a look in the mirror
and see what is really there look back on your achievements and your accomplishments hold a
retrospective for yourself in the same way you would do for a project
but make sure you're completing an objective evaluation of your skills because this will allow us to distinguish reality from
what our imposter syndrome has been telling us focus on what you have done well and
facts and what could be improved and use that to move forward this reflection
is really the critical piece that i feel holds it all together and how i've been able to continue my
fight and not let imposter syndrome hold me back one of my favorite ways to do my
reflection is by keeping a journal write down all a list of different achievements write
down things you're proud of things you've completed write down goals and stepping stones to success
and then look back reflect on them mark things off when you've finished them how much progress have you
made look at your past projects go through the depths of your github repo and compare to current ones
have you made progress have you improved most importantly have you learned
likely it's likely that you have without even realizing it in my journal i just write down all of
the things even even the good and the bad but i'm always surprised by what i have
accomplished in times where i feel like i'm not making that progress these notes help to
prove otherwise and help me to practice turning my negative thoughts into positive ones
and listening successes can shift your focus from your weaknesses onto your strengths
and it can really create a basis of facts to guide your self-reflection
but we all know an objective evaluation of yourself can be very challenging so we can use
the help of others by asking for feedback so go out to your colleagues and your teammates and
collect feedback on yourself ask them how you think you've performed and
what they think you have done well but also learn to value constructive criticism and use
that to move forward and get better because if you're not looking to improve you actually end up holding your team back
and slowing your team down and really no one expects you to know everything right away the grads
would come to me
all right so the the grads would come to me uh feeling like a fraud and my response to them was
always to get feedback and they were often surprised with the result there was one graduate
who came to me saying she didn't understand why the senior was spending so much time pairing with
her and working closely with her and when i spoke to the senior he said he was proud of her that she
had made really good progress and she was contributing to the team and she was a really valued team member
so it was all a matter of perspective the expectations that the graduates had
put on themselves did not match reality we are harder on ourselves than anyone else but
getting that feedback can really help us to recognize rationalize and reflect
and shift those negative thoughts into positive ones and help us all to be proud of ourselves
an issue with the the current climate is the way we see the lives of others
hannes touched on this in his talk yesterday when he was talking about success is all a matter of perspective
right now everything is online and we're not actually exposed to the full picture of people's
lives so this virtual world means it's it's a skewed view and it's really easy to misinterpret
we can see all the achievements and success that people are posting on twitter linkedin or wherever it may be
we can see them finishing projects and publishing blogs and getting promoted
but then we see ourselves with our failures as well we can see ourselves who don't
have any side projects who really struggle to keep up with our blog and was not successful in that last
promotion social media encourages a unhelpful social comparison and it can really
amplify that dissatisfaction in imposter syndrome that we are suffering from
so we need to learn how to separate the virtual world from reality we can use facts about
yourself and others and really reflect on the positives and what you know to be
true my friend told mike kennen brooks you're obviously doing something right
so you should probably just keep going think through how did you get to where you are was it
luck or was it the hard work and effort that you put in someone gave you that role that job that
opportunity for a reason bill gates said here don't compare yourself with anyone in
this world if you do so you are insulting yourself everyone has
their own story their own pathways and talents and you are awesome for your own reasons
they hired you not because they expected you to know everything but because they saw potential in you
use yourself as your bases for your reflection and your god most of us don't actually know what
we're doing and we don't know everything and that's okay you can use it as motivation
to go out and learn more you can challenge the negative thoughts and practice that positive self-talk
practice bringing up the second voice from the negative one start and make the choice to fight back you
can flip limiting beliefs and use it as a challenge a motivation to prove yourself wrong when you hear
that little voice in your head saying oh i can't do it i'm not good enough fight back and tell yourself you are
good enough you can do it but also remember it's okay to fail
the important thing is that you learn and reflect on the experience so when i was in the graduate manager
role i had recognized i was experiencing imposter syndrome and worked through it by rationalizing
those thoughts and i figured you know actually i had done well and there was no mistake
in them giving me this role however i could then clearly see i was
not happy in the role and it just was not for me i missed the hands-on tech so i cut the
secondment short and moved back to a developer role
but i was able to stay motivated and use my experience as a positive one
and i continued to reflect on my achievements and even now i can look back at the
steps i took and how i grew from that and what i learned from it
and i can look at my goals and iterate on them and create new ones if we practice
recognizing rationalizing and reflecting we can beat imposter syndrome
so what can you do so far we focused a whole lot on how you can manage imposter syndrome for
yourself but you can also help others who are experiencing imposter syndrome
if you're one of the lucky ones who don't experience it then make sure you reach out to your
friends and colleagues and help them if they might be experiencing it you can support other people in their
fight you can become a mentor to people who you see potential in or who you think might need
that little extra push you can educate somebody who you think might be experiencing it
he can help provide the tools that they need to beat imposter syndrome you can teach them how to recognize it
how to help them rationalize their feelings and how to reflect on their
accomplishments guide them to opportunities they might not normally seek out themselves for
fear of failing or lack of confidence when i was a graduate i shared my interest
in a leadership role with a colleague and then when the opportunity for the
graduate manager came up he approached me and told me he thought i would be really good at it and i
should apply my immediate reaction was no way
i would not be successful in getting the role let alone being good at it but with his support i
applied and i was successful and later on when i was applying to
roles when i was moving to melbourne i applied to senior level positions despite at the time being a mid-tier
developer and i only did this because my manager had told me that he saw me reaching that
senior level so without him telling me that i would not have had the confidence to do so
and he believed in me and that made me believe in myself to create a mentor program
at your company or get involved in one that already exists you can be that person that helps
fight helps with somebody's fight with imposter syndrome give a all your new starters a buddy and
someone they can lean on because they might not be comfortable enough with people in your company yet
imposter syndrome can strike at all levels so that means we need to have the support there as well
really everyone needs a champion everyone needs somebody that can put their name forward especially you know if they might be a
bit hesitant to do so themselves but also having a just a one-soft conversation
is really not enough just going up to somebody saying hey i think you should do this once once you leave they might be like
oh no i can't do that so you need to have a continued plan and offer that ongoing support
and continue to give them those nudges help encourage the self-reflection by
driving goal-setting and set up a career and coaching plan
studies have shown that coaching and career planning leads to a positive effect on people's
confidence and pushes them up in the fight against imposter syndrome and so you can be that one who gives the
confidence to somebody who needs it
we've talked about how impostors should collect feedback on themselves but you see you can also go out and give
it reach out to your teammates and your colleagues and provide feedback to help help them reflect on
their accomplishments it can really help them with the thought stopping thought shipping
and reflection and help people to grow tell people when they have done well say
i love your work and create a system for your team to be able to recognize each other
and really celebrate success i know microsoft teams and linkedin both have
built-in tools that allow you to send praise and shout outs to colleagues and in my company we have a monthly
discover master influence award where you can nominate a teammate who has gone above
and beyond and in return they'll receive a gift card for their efforts but even if they initially brush it off
or make up some excuse this continual feedback and celebration of success
can help wear down the negative thoughts and really build up the positive ones
but make sure you give people credit for their strengths and let them know why you hired them why you think they would be good for
that opportunity otherwise they might just be questioning why they ended up there
to let them know what they have achieved using facts focus on what they've done well and
explain how it was done well and really help credit their success to internal factors
because one of the the main things with imposter syndrome is that we struggle to internalize our
success
within your team you can also nurture a growth mindset and this is the idea that you can
develop intelligence and skill and having an open mind for learning and
failure and change the growth mindset leads to higher productivity
more achievement and just in general higher life satisfaction
a fixed mindset on the other hand is the belief that intelligence is static and cannot be changed and this can
really hold us back but unfortunately a fixed mindset often accompanies imposter syndrome and feeds into it it
can drive the worries that you don't belong or you will just never be good enough so if we develop a growth
mindset within our team we can challenge this help your team to view
any sort of setbacks or struggles as an opportunity and make sure you don't reprimand mistakes but use them
as a way to learn so help people appraise a new attempt in a well-directed effort
or challenging the status quo and strive away from just praising on intelligence alone
use facts and really shape your your praise to give them a clear picture
as to why they should be there help guide their self-reflection and their journey outside of mentoring
and support we can create a positive culture and working environment for our team by fostering community and diversity and
inclusion we can remove any sort of blame culture and competition that can drive imposter syndrome and
create a safe place where people can really be themselves where they feel comfortable to share
those ideas and challenge the ways and learn from them dr valerie young
found a sense of belonging fosters confidence and we already know that minorities and
people outside of their comfort zone experience imposter syndrome at a higher rate so focusing on that diversity inclusion
and positive culture can help to remove some of those barriers the more people
around you who look and sound like you the more comfortable you feel and the more welcoming people are the
more confident you are so having that confidence and comfort can really help your team to speak up
and believe in themselves and really work to their full potential
imposter syndrome can be a good thing it doesn't always have to be bad we can use it as a challenge to prove
herself wrong and anyone else who may be thinking we're an imposter
mike in his talk found himself in a situation where he did not know the things that people
expected him to but instead of freezing he used it as an exp
excuse to go out and learn to go out and figure out the information that people
were expecting him to have he may have done it out of fear of looking like a fraud or being found out
but he used it as a force for good so you can motivate yourself to take on
that new challenge and prove yourself and everyone else wrong and remember that it's okay to not know
everything and it's okay to fail keep learning and fight against imposter syndrome really imposter
syndrome can make us stronger through all this recognizing rationalizing and self-reflection
we learn to recognize our feelings and we drive our self-awareness and our emotional
intelligence we get comfortable with being uncomfortable and it really helps us to learn about
who we are helps us to learn about ourselves and but to also open up and connect to other people and
